author: Anuradha Raman
text:
With a single-judge commission of inquiry examining the reasons why Hyderabad University research scholar Rohith Vemula committed suicide still under way, and the HRD Ministry committee’s report on the failings of the administration to reach out to students, Vice-Chancellor Appa Rao Podile resumed work on Tuesday after a two-month break, catching the Human Resource Development Ministry by surprise.

“Just when we felt things had quietened down a bit, he has resumed work today amid protests by students,” a Ministry official said.

Mr. Podile downplayed his return saying he had to return to work. Ministry officials said they were closely monitoring the situation. Speaking to The Hindu , Mr. Podile said his colleagues’ insistence had made him return to work. “Two months is a long time and a lot of work needs to be done,” Mr. Podile said, adding recruitments to both teaching and non-teaching staff had to be undertaken. Mr. Podile says his return is based on the understanding that the commission under retired Justice Ashok K. Roopanwal had almost concluded its work of speaking to all stakeholders of the campus.

Mr. Podile said his office had sent an email to the MHRD as soon as he decided to resume work.

“As the students have broken my computer, I have not checked my mail or the response of the Ministry.”

The Vice-Chancellor said he would consult the deans of schools before taking any action against the students who had ransacked his office. A month ago, a fact-finding report of the MHRD had noted that the administration had failed to engage with the striking students which had escalated the crisis. The judicial commission is expected to submit its report in April.
title: HRD Ministry surprised at varsity V-C’s return
